channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Scotland to launch vaccine passports on 1 October
item.description: Plans to only allow fully vaccinated people into nightclubs and other large events are approved by MSPs.

item.title: Thirteen UK citizens leave Kabul as flights resume
item.description: Dozens of people, including 13 UK citizens, take a plane from Kabul to Qatar's capital Doha.

item.title: Biden administration sues Texas over restrictive abortion law
item.description: The Texas law effectively bans abortions from as early as six weeks into a pregnancy.

item.title: Amazon offers to pay college fees for 750,000 US staff
item.description: The online shopping giant says all US frontline workers will be eligible as it fights to attract new employees.

item.title: National Television Awards 2021: Ant and Dec 'overwhelmed' by 20th win
item.description: The duo have won the TV presenting prize at the National Television Awards every year since 2001.

item.title: Mercury Prize 2021: Arlo Parks wins for Collapsed In Sunbeams
item.description: Soul singer Arlo Parks scoops the 2021 Mercury Prize for her debut album, Collapsed In Sunbeams.

item.title: Afghanistan: Journalists tell of beatings by Taliban
item.description: Reporter Taqi Daryabi tells the BBC he was kicked in the face and beaten with sticks by Taliban fighters.

item.title: Grenfell risk assessor reckless over cladding, inquiry hears
item.description: An expert witness criticises the decision to sign off the tower's cladding as safe without evidence.

item.title: Teenager Raducanu prepares for US Open semi
item.description: Emma Raducanu says it is a "weird feeling" to be one of the few remaining players in the locker room after reaching the US Open semi-finals.

item.title: University of South Wales: Hacker jailed for selling exam answers
item.description: Hayder Aljayyash was sentenced to 20 months after breaking into University of South Wales' systems.

item.title: Comedian dropped from Covid ads over tweets
item.description: The Glasgow comedian admitted the tweets, from several years ago, had "terrible, horrific undertones".

item.title: Don't mix business and public duty, Tory co-chair Ben Elliot told
item.description: Party co-chair Ben Elliot is warned to be "cautious" and avoid lobbying on behalf of business clients.

item.title: Hong Kong: Police raid Tiananmen Square museum
item.description: The raid comes a day after four members of the group that ran the venue were arrested.

item.title: WW2 pilot has 100th birthday flight over Shropshire
item.description: John Trotman, twice awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, has got behind the controls once more.

item.title: National Television Awards: Stars hit the red carpet
item.description: It's the first big awards night for British TV since the pandemic began.

item.title: Deutsche Börse Photography Foundation Prize 2021 winner revealed
item.description: Cao Fei won the Deutsche Börse Photography Foundation Prize for her work reflecting our digital age.

item.title: Genesis: Tour ‘putting it to bed’ after 54 years
item.description: The singer is returning on tour with Genesis despite ongoing health problems.

item.title: Rio Ferdinand: 'I have to explain the monkey emoji to my kids'
item.description: Former England footballer Rio Ferdinand tells MPs about his experience of online hate and racism.

item.title: Ray-Ban Stories: Facebook reveals its video camera glasses
item.description: Facebook and eyewear brand Ray-Ban have revealed a pair of glasses that contain two cameras.

item.title: US: Colorado City will pay $3m to a woman with dementia injured by police
item.description: Bodycam footage shows the moment Colorado City officers detained and injured 75-year-old Karen Garner.

item.title: Great Yarmouth and the man who has holidayed there for 75 years
item.description: George Bennett first visited Great Yarmouth at the age of four and has been back each year since.

item.title: McDonald's plant burger launch late to vegan party
item.description: The chain announces its McPlant burger will be on offer nationwide next year, after years of research.

item.title: 'My flight home was booked for two weeks ago'
item.description: British teenager Emma Raducanu expresses her surprise at her run to the US Open semi-finals, having had flights back to the UK booked a fortnight ago.

item.title: Afghan Special Forces commander faced race against time to flee
item.description: An Afghan Special Forces commander says he owes his life to members of the Parachute Regiment who helped him escape.

item.title: Leicestershire sisters on track for Olympic glory
item.description: Indienne and Shaikira have both recently been crowned national champions.

item.title: Lebanon: A country plunged into darkness
item.description: Lebanon’s ongoing crisis has plunged the country into darkness, with some experiencing power cuts for 20 hours a day.

item.title: Why people in Eswatini are protesting
item.description: Eswatini is Africa’s last absolute monarchy, which means the king controls everything.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Who rescues migrants in the Channel?
item.description: The number of migrants crossing the English Channel is increasing, but who is responsible for them?

item.title: ‘Havana syndrome ’ and the mystery of the microwaves
item.description: The BBC investigates a mystery illness dubbed "Havana syndrome" that has affected American diplomats and spies.

item.title: Will Boris Johnson’s plan for the NHS work?
item.description: The prime minister believes new funds will tackle the Covid backlog - but refuses to set targets.

item.title: Social care: Will people still have to sell their homes?
item.description: In 2019, the Conservatives pledged no-one should have to sell their home to pay for their care.

item.title: The Kenyans who are helping the world to cheat
item.description: Some Kenyans try to escape poverty by helping foreign students to fake their academic work.

item.title: The models that turned Instagram into their DIY catwalk
item.description: New York Fashion Week marks a tentative return - but how did supermodels keep working through Covid?

item.title: Respect: Jennifer Hudson on embodying soul legend Aretha Franklin
item.description: The singer was personally selected by soul legend Franklin to play her in the new biopic Respect.

item.title: How green is Scotland's space industry?
item.description: Scotland's thriving space sector is trying to have a reduced impact on the planet.

item.title: How a monkey launched the pop-it toy craze
item.description: Why it took a TikTok primate to turn a forty-year-old idea into a global hit

item.title: Teenager Hodgkinson caps stunning year by claiming Diamond League title - video & report
item.description: British teenager Keely Hodgkinson wins the Diamond League 800m title to bank $30,000 in prize money and cap an extraordinary year.

item.title: England win thriller against New Zealand to clinch T20 series - report & highlights
item.description: England win the decisive final match against New Zealand by four wickets with one ball to spare at Taunton, to win the women's Twenty20 international series 2-1.

item.title: 'I am not here for a vacation' - Ronaldo ready for Man Utd homecoming
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo says he has not returned to Manchester United "for a vacation" as the Portugal captain prepares for his Old Trafford homecoming against Newcastle on Saturday.

item.title: Fifth Test between England and India set to go ahead
item.description: The fifth Test between England and India is set to go ahead after no further positive Covid-19 tests were returned by the tourists.

item.title: Miedema hits 100 as Arsenal reach Champions League group stage
item.description: Vivianne Miedema makes it to 100 Arsenal goals with a hat-trick as the Gunners blitz Slavia Prague 4-0 to reach the Champions League group stage.

item.title: 'Purists will say it's ridiculous, but boxing is evolving' - Haye, 40, defends comeback
item.description: David Haye believes "boxing is evolving" for the better as he prepares to make his comeback aged 40.

item.title: England v New Zealand T20: Watch thrilling finale as hosts clinch series win in Taunton
item.description: Watch the thrilling finale as New Zealand take two late wickets before England's Sophia Dunkley hits a four from the penultimate ball to win the Twenty20 international series decider at Taunton.

item.title: Covid: How do I get the vaccine and will I need a booster?
item.description: A third dose is being offered to up to half a million people in the UK with weakened immune systems.

item.title: Covid passports: Will I need one for nightclubs, concerts and festivals?
item.description: People in Scotland will need to be fully vaccinated to go to clubs, sporting events and concerts.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Many children are returning to school after the holidays, while Scottish pupils already returned.

item.title: Covid: Will I need a jab and what will university be like this term?
item.description: Many Covid restrictions have been lifted for students going to university this term.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's population, as more than 48 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Millions of children, including 16- to 17-year-olds, are now being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: The furlough scheme, which protected millions of jobs during the pandemic, is in its final weeks.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: Afghanistan: Could Pakistani drones hit the Panjshir Valley?
item.description: There are claims that Pakistan has used drones against anti-Taliban forces in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: The pledge binding al-Qaeda to the Taliban
item.description: The history of the complex relationship between the two groups.

item.title: Taliban needs UN's humanitarian aid - UN boss
item.description: In return, the new regime must provide conditions for the UN to work in Afghanistan, secretary general tells BBC.

item.title: Afghanistan: Dentist fears for family in hiding from Taliban
item.description: Suleyman Sakha says his in-laws, who worked for a humanitarian organisation, are living in dread.

item.title: Afghanistan: Who's who in the Taliban leadership
item.description: What we know about the top figures in the militant group that has taken control of Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Rural areas welcome peace and end of war
item.description: In more rural areas of Afghanistan, people welcome the end of a war that has killed tens of thousands.

item.title: The Taliban embrace social media: 'We too want to change perceptions'
item.description: Famed for their shunning of technology, the Taliban are realising they need to be on social media too.

item.title: US Senator Lindsey Graham: 'We will be going back into Afghanistan'
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham believes there will be no choice as "the threat will be so large".

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.
